messageBody:
It lessens the burden of typing when you have to add more classes, but
otherwise this approach seems too complicated for my PERSONAL taste when
it comes to dealing with tests. I view the tests as the API spec in
most respects -- this kind of code (though it's a simple example) just
makes the tests harder to understand. Nevertheless, if you are going to
use it, make sure you put a String in that ctor for
AbstractEnhancedTextfieldTest.

=jason

On Wed, 2002-08-07 at 10:10, Mark Meyers wrote: What about some
reflection ?
(note argumentTypes can easily made from arguments, and classes could be
dynamicaly found, but that is not so simple)
Jason's remark about using Collections/Iterators still stands, of
course.

public TestSuite suite(){
TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();

Class[] classes = {ChildA, ChildB};
Object[][] arguments = {{}, {"testtext"},{"testtext", new
Integer(5)}};
Class[][] argumentTypes = {{}, {String.class}, {String.class,
Integer.class}};

for(int i=0;i<classes.length;i++){
for(int j=0;j<arguments.length;j++){
Object testSubject =
classes[i].getConstructor(argumentTypes[j]).newInstance(arguments[j]);
AbstractEnhancedTextfieldTest test = new
AbstractEnhancedTextfieldTest();
test.setMyTextfield(testSubject);
suite.add(test);
}
}
}

> A little cleaner approach would be to set them in lists and have the
> tests iterate over the lists. Each test method then iterates over the
> list of Components and performs its asserts/fails on each
> member of the
> list. This list is most cleanly initialized in the abstract test's
> setUp(). Of course that means that every time you execute a test, you
> re-initialize the list of components (I would prefer that), but if you
> don't want to do that use the TestSetup class.
>
> There is really no need for embedding a class definition in the suite
> method.
>
> =jason
